bboxes.raw_text:
Women who wish to enter the
Feb. 18th class of Southwestern
Preparatory School for medical
secretaries, should contact the
registrars office as soon as
possible, said Wallace A. Reed,
M. D.


Doctor Reed, president of the
Maricopa County Medical So
ciety. sponsors of the school,
added enro llment in the February
class is nearly filled.


Response to the school has been
SO great that enrolment in next
winter s classes is already being
accepted.


Noting that Southwestern Pre-

MEDICAL SECRETARY CLASSES
TO OPEN FEB. 18th

Disabled veterans and depend
ents of deceased veterans
throughout Arizona who receive
monthly pension payments and
are now reporting their annual
income to the Veterans Admin
istration are urged to remem-
Der to sign the reports.


Wayne Sanders, Manager of
the VA regional office in Phoenix
said that every year thousands
of income reports have to be
returned to the pension recip-
tents for a signature.


The law requires that pensions
be paid only to persons whose
annual income Is less than stip-
ulated amounts. Thus each year,
an income report must be made
to determine eligibility.


A signature is necessary on
the report, Sanders said.

VA HEAD SAYS
SIGN PENSION
REPORTS

Lloyd Clayton Reed, 80, dis
obeyed a peace bond order and
died from gunshot wounds in the
head. He was slain by Mrs. Betty
G. Thompson, %, 7l6-D South
10th Ave.. who called police to
surrender after the shooting oc-
Cured.


She told police she fired the y
caliber revolver after Reed
grabbed her arm and tried to
force her into a bedroom.


Mrs. Thompson has five chill
dren, ages E months to S years,
who we're at her home during the
shooting.

MAN SLAIN


BY WOMAN WHO
HAD HIM UNDER
A PEACE BOND

paratory School is the only school
for medical secretaries in the
United States which is sponsored
by medical society, Doctor Reed
said that its organization has at.
tracted nationwide attention. In
quiries have been received from
medical societies, state organi-
cations, and important clinics
throughout the country, indicat-
ing that the need for trained med
ical office help exists nationally,
as well as within Arizona's ex-
banding medical profession.


Interested women should call
Mrs. Zoya Parrish, registrar,
252-567l.

Jam sessions have been
changed from Thursday nights to
Wednesday.


Our bowling team needs mem
bers. Meet the bowlers here
each Monday at $50 pm. Bowl
at Southern Lanes.


Antler Guard meets the first
and third Thursday of each month.
1t will sponsor a Western Dance
on Jan. Is.


Jan. 26-PSA convention COM
mittee will meet at 4 pm. All
members are asked to attend.


Mr.. John Weber, l0o So. IL
ST.. is recuperating from sur
gerry.


DIT. Emma hurry is Ill at Mar
icopa County Hospital. Ward 81.


Bob Hunter, exalted ruler of
Navajo Lodge 1868, Albuquerque,
New Mexico, is visiting our city.

NEW YORK The recently
announced program of the Flea
nor Roosevelt Memorial Founda-
tion for recruiting returning
Peace Corps members for in
terneship training with estab-
Hshed civil rights organizations
has been praised as a helpful
contribution to the Fight for
Freedom by NAACP Executive
Secretary Roy Wilkins and other
civil rights leaders.


In an hour Long program tele-
Wsed over the facilities OF
WABC-TV here, Sunday, Jan. II,
a panel of experts talked on the
Foundation s new program and
other aspects of the civil rights
struggle.


Among those appearing on the
program with Mr.. Wilkins we're
Whitney Young, executive direc-
tor, National Urban League:
Stanley Lowell. chairman, New
York City Commission onHuman
Rights: Hyman Bookbinder. ex-
ecutive director, Eleanor Roose-
welt Memorial Foundation: John
Field, former executive direc-
tor, the President S Committee
on Equal Employment Opportun-
ity: and William Butell, an ABC
commentator, who served as
moderator.

AUSTIN, Texas-The eight year
prison sentence of Billy Sol Estes
financial wizard and evangelist,
was upheld by the highest state
court for criminal cases.


Estes. 38. was convicted in
1862 of swindling. A Is yr. SEN
tence is still on appeal in fed
eral court.

full articles.headline:
ESTES SENTENCE
UPHELD
full articles.article:
AUSTIN, Texas-The eight year
prison sentence of Billy Sol Estes
financial wizard and evangelist,
